DataElement.preferredName: New Tumor Prior To Resection Radiologic Tumor Burden Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value of the sum of the maximum diameter of the new tumor as reported on the computed tomography or magnetic resonance imaging immediately preceding the surgical resection.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: New Tumor Prior To Resection Radiologic Tumor Burden
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation.  Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Earlier in time or order._Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement._The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ._The use of radiation (such as x-rays) or other imaging technologies (such as ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging) to diagnose or treat disease._Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body. Also called tumor load.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: New; having no previous example or precedent or parallel.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: Having no previous example or precedent or parallel; of a kind not seen before.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Also called tumor load.

Concepts.definition: Used as a function word to indicate direction, purpose, or movement.
The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
The branch of medical science dealing with the medical use of X-rays or other penetrating radiation.
Refers to the number of cancer cells, the size of a tumor, or the amount of cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: any measurements, including linear dimensions, volume, and weight, of a patient's tumor.
